I prepared all the possible icons for the compose message:
image.png
I'm not sure we do want to display them all...

Wrapping them doesn't look cool, but as a responsively solution might be ok.
image.png
I think if we reorder icons from left to right so the most frequently used and desirable would be on the left side, while on the right side would be those to collapse
That could work, but I'd worry that even with that layout issue solved it would be an intimidatingly long list -- it could feel more like using MS Word than using a chat tool.
Right, that's the point. We have to limit that list or at least don't show all the options until clicked on "more options button".

As mentioned in #20302, we probably should not do:

  • Headings
  • Tables
  • Horizontal lines
  • /todo (can consider once feature is more polished)
It might still be too much, but at least somewhat less than the screenshots above.
Actually, I'm not sure everything from #20302 is represented?
Specifically @-mentions and spoilers.
But anyway, agreed, we'll probably need to figure out a good way to hide some of the buttons (assuming we think they are all useful).
Regarding the icons, there are a couple that aren't obvious to me -- what is the C in a box? And the piece of paper with a line at the bottom?
I would guess that c in box is supposed to be code block, but that's only because I use code blocks a lot.
but then we also have <> so I guess I have no clue.

For reference, this is a screenshot from the in-progress PR #20672 to add compose box buttons:

147888401-1f2fdcff-9cc9-48fa-bd83-140eb12ccf14.png
Vlad, we have a popover for icon that don't fit in the line. We can just use that.
looking good!

@Alya Abbott good catch!
Well I prepared that screen to feedback multiple things at the same time.
I've read in issue "Probably not needed" and thought, just let me try if we might, how bad is that. I was looking for the top limit of the icon quantity. Removing/hiding is always easy, we just don't do it :)

For tables in future I would suggest a single button which opens another row, but I have hard time imagining that somebody seriously want to compose tables in a message.

I'm a bit confused with @. Why would we need to add it if many people are already educated about it, and using @ would probably require to type some characters of a name. Same with headers and lists. Its just a symbol before, not even 2 symbols around.

Spolers. I see that I failed here as a designer :) image.png
I just didn't think that Minus icon is recognizable at all.

what is the C in a box

Oh, thats another failure. I thought its a bit confusing to have <> and <> with a document icon I guess I was wrong.
I initially did M for Monospace, but nobody refers to it like this in a UI, so I made C for code and put it next other inline formatters, because that is what it is... so C is for making a monospaced text, while '<>' is for a code block. I guess I should make it like in Slack which is also like the screenshot from the PR

x2 is a bit confusing. Is it formula block or it is inline formula?

I actually thing that for inline formula and inline code we should not expose icons... if there is no task to make WYSIWYG editor. If click on an icon have idea of a selection in mind it could understand if the selected should be inline code (less than a single line is selected) or a code block (multiple lines with at least a line break are selected). And if we don't have any of such logic yet, its ok to don't provide an icon for a very single character input to learn.

What I now see as a good thing from the screenshot is that Help isn't an icon but a text - a good distinction.

So I'll come back with code and codeblock icon change + popup list button
Do you guys have any other ideas about spoler icon if not a minus? Could you help me to understand what do you think looking on image.png ? I thought idea of a page part is very close to spoiler feature

Thanks for the clarifications Vlad Korobov !

x2 is a bit confusing. Is it formula block or it is inline formula?

That one inserts LaTeX formatting.

I actually thing that for inline formula and inline code we should not expose icons... if there is no task to make WYSIWYG editor. If click on an icon have idea of a selection in mind it could understand if the selected should be inline code (less than a single line is selected) or a code block (multiple lines with at least a line break are selected). And if we don't have any of such logic yet, its ok to don't provide an icon for a very single character input to learn.

Mm, that's a good idea. @Julia Bichler has already implemented smart selection behavior for LaTeX, where it inserts $$ or ```math depending on the current selection. So I like the proposal to make the code formatting conditioned on the selection, and to insert ``` formatting if there is no selection. And then you'd just type a ` if you need in-line code.

It might be worth brainstorming more about the spoiler icon. I don't think the current - one is super clear, but I'm not sure about the half-page either.

The nice thing is that the user can pretty easily figure it out by hovering to get a tooltip or clicking on it, even if we can't make it totally clear.
LaTeX is a block right? Or $$ e^{i \pi} + 1 = 0 $$ this is LaTeX while block is Math-block?

Both $$ and ```math are LaTeX. The difference is that $$ is inline: eiπ+1=0e^{i\pi} + 1 = 0eiπ+1=0, while ```math is display:

eiπ+1=0e^{i\pi} + 1 = 0eiπ+1=0
ok, so please tell me what the button x2 is supposed to do exactly?
Glancing at the code for the PR, it looks like it adds $$s.
Oh, unless the selected text has newlines, when it switches to ```math

Mm, that's a good idea. Julia Bichler has already implemented smart selection behavior for LaTeX, where it inserts $$ or ```math depending on the current selection. So I like the proposal to make the code formatting conditioned on the selection, and to insert ``` formatting if there is no selection. And then you'd just type a ` if you need in-line code.

I agree that it makes sense to only have one button for this, should i include this in my pull request too?

Julia Bichler said:

I agree that it makes sense to only have one button for this, should i include this in my pull request too?

Yes, that would be great -- thanks!

Alex Vandiver said:

Oh, unless the selected text has newlines, when it switches to ```math

Right, I think this is exactly analogous to Vlad's proposal for having a single button to insert code.
Do we really need buttons to insert - and 1. to make list item for the people in the current compose box?

We would not add those buttons until #20305 is implemented.

The interaction where one really wants a button is being able to select a bunch of lines and immediately turn them into a list. This usually comes up from me when I copy-paste text from outside Zulip and the list formatting disappears in the process.

Alya Abbott said:

The interaction where one really wants a button is being able to select a bunch of lines and immediately turn them into a list. This usually comes up from me when I copy-paste text from outside Zulip and the list formatting disappears in the process.

Note that we also could directly work on making the list formatting not disappear in the process to make that less important of a consideration. We have a feature of this form that's limited to the development environment because it has issues that need to be resolved.

But I also do think it is instructive that GitHub includes lists in its set of formatting buttons.

Note that we also could directly work on making the list formatting not disappear in the process to make that less important of a consideration.

Heh, yes, this would be great too. :)
#5928 is the issue for preserving some formatting on copy-paste.

Alya Abbott said:

Yes, that would be great -- thanks!

Okay, i will do that :)
@Vlad Korobov is there somewhere one can browse around the icon set you used here?
It is not a set yet, but I could prepare it so people can grab

Got it.

How do folks feel about this set? I think it looks nice overall, but it's worth brainstorming more about the spoiler icon, at least. Other thoughts?
What do you guys think about the LaTeX icon?
For spoilers, maybe we can come up with an idea around the metaphor of rolling something up? https://www.istockphoto.com/vector/roll-up-banners-icon-vector-illustration-gm930034890-255004628
Do other services with a spoiler syntax like stack overflow have an icon they use?
Holy cow that a lot of visual noise. Why are the icons needed at all?

I think we haven't made a decision on precisely what set of features belong in top-level icons vs. a side menu. But the intent is to make it convenient to use the various markup features that currently require reading our Markdown help to access.

Tim Abbott said:

Do other services with a spoiler syntax like stack overflow have an icon they use?

Stackoverflow doesn't have an icon for that: image.png
Github has even a different syntax for that like a custom html tag <details> and no button

So in general its not something that other products expose as an icon

Tim Abbott said:

I think we haven't made a decision on precisely what set of features belong in top-level icons vs. a side menu. But the intent is to make it convenient to use the various markup features that currently require reading our Markdown help to access.

Right, the images Vlad Korobov posted above are meant to showcase a library of icons we can choose from. We do not plan to actually use all of them this way.

We get a lot of traffic to https://zulip.com/help/format-your-message-using-markdown, which I think suggests that we could be doing a better job of teaching folks how to do message formatting directly within Zulip. Adding some buttons that insert the appropriate formatting is one way to do that.

Tim Abbott said:

Do other services with a spoiler syntax like stack overflow have an icon they use?

There's a Slack spoiler app that uses a two-colored exclamation mark:

Screen-Shot-2022-01-21-at-1.13.08-PM.png

It doesn't actually look good when it's small (if ever), so I'm not recommending that we copy it. :)

Update on compose icons

Video clarification 8 mins
UI prototype to click through or jump through with arrow keys.
General idea is to separate expanded compose icons row and responsivity of the compose icons row. Details are in the video and prototype.
Here is a picture with all the icons, including updated ones:
compose-03-03.png

I also made icons in preview mode disabled, since we don't support editing in the preview mode yet.

It feels like a bug that currently in Zulip I can not edit text in the preview mode but I can click icon buttons.

It should be noted that we are currently also using the pencil-box icon for the "Sign up" button for logged out users (in the not-yet-deployed work on enabling logged out access). It will be good not to have the same icon in the compose box anymore.

Screen-Shot-2022-01-27-at-12.47.49-PM.png
Those button icons should be removed though. They’re too noisy and don’t really clarify the buttons or save you from having to read the text.
Heh, fair enough. CC @Aman Agrawal (amanagr)
Yes, agree that there should be no icons on those
Opened #20955

It would be great to get some feedback on Vlad Korobov 's proposal above:

  1. Do folks like the specific icons? Anything we should change before Vlad Korobov puts in the work to make them usable?
  2. Thoughts on the proposal to use "..." to expand/reduce the number of icons shown?
  3. Thoughts on having the icons wrap to multiple rows in narrow windows, replacing the overflow menu we're currently using?
  4. Thoughts on moving Drafts and Help to the upper right of the compose box?
One thing I just noticed is that we're using the same icon for Recent topics and <time. Since they are totally different concepts, ideally the icons would be different as well.

I'm not sure I like the idea of moving "Drafts" and ?, since they are quite different from the ^ and X buttons next to them, which are used for managing the compose box. Though none of the placements for those two that we've tried seem great.

1. I like the icons.

2,3. Using a popover is better in this case. On screen sizes like 320 to 450px, the expand approach will produce like 4-5 lines of icons. There will be little space for the textbox and message list left. We can test out both approaches to be sure.

  1. I think that's reasonable. I would expect to find help icon there.

popover vs not popover doesn't make difference in terms of the space usage, but it does make difference in ability to click on things you want and have them reliably available.
I agree that for mobile such experience isn't ideal. But should I treat web narrow version as mobile experience?
The solution for mobile users could be a horizontally scrollable line of icons. We could also make it scrollable horizontally even if a user scrolls vertically with a mouse weal there. Also we could take more old fashion approach of having <``> buttons there.

But should I treat web narrow version as mobile experience?

Yes, since they look alike. I am sure buttons in a popover are more readily available than a scrollable list of icons. Also, you can memory map them. So, you know where to look for an icon in a popover in your next attempt.
if you don't have enough space you can switch off expanded list of icons

I would have the same logic for the web version, for the the mobile app I would approach things similarly to iOS tooltip, where there is horizontal scroll via buttons.
I just think that for mobile version dialog with additional icons is acceptable, while for desktop version in majority of cases I would prefer them to not disappear if I want to see them all.

Horizontal scrollable elements can be very tricky to identify. So, if we don't want popover for desktop screens, we can experiment some other design idea? Should we postpone this discussion until we have them icons?
Well, we already use the ... paradigm to hide some icons on narrow screens, though it might not come up that much outside of mobile web for now.

Heh, I checked what Gmail does, and it looks rather silly. Note that the ... in the bottom right area also hides some actions.

Screen-Shot-2022-02-10-at-8.54.21-AM.png

Thanks for working on the compose icons! Here's my personal reactions to them:

  • The Preview and Link icons aren't immediately recognizable to me as what they're supposed to be -- not sure I can readily express why.
  • The eyes on the emoji icon feel hard to make out (they kinda disappear for me below a certain size); maybe they'd benefit from a few more pixels. I think the ? icon in the top-right shares this issue.
  • The video call icon looks too square to me; maybe it could be less tall preserving the rest of the design?
  • Is the person with a checkmark meant to be a poll? It's not recognizable to me. I guess the problem is that the natural icons for poll and TODO are very similar. https://help.twitter.com/en/using-twitter/twitter-polls suggests Twitter uses a sideways bar graph for their polls icon; that might be a good direction since that's somewhat standard and we don't have a graphing feature it would compete with.
  • The scroll icon, is also a bit mysterious, but I think that's probably fundamental to the fact that this isn't a standard icon for the concept. I think it looks quite nice, and presumably you can get the label "Spoiler" via hover.
  • The numbered/bulleted list icons feel hard to parse for me; the unordered list reminds me a bit of a dot next to a hamburger menu. I think I'd be happier with a model similar to GitHub's where they have dots next to each line for \ul, and 2 numbers for \ol.
  • The rest look good to me.

I guess another thing I want to note -- I imagine that for the subset of these icons that we use across the application (E.g. the emoji one), we'd want to change it across the app? It might just be that one, actually, so I guess we should just make sure to test it in the other contexts we use it (E.g. the emoji icon might appear in a slightly smaller form on message bodies, so we should make sure it looks clear there too).
thank you for the detailed feedback, will respond later

While I'm thinking about it let me know which icons you can read better or feel better about them:
image.png

Vlad Korobov said:

While I'm thinking about it let me know which icons you can read better or feel better about them:
image.png

2/3rd row from the top feels good to me.

Here are my opinions on them:

Preview eye

image

  1. Since it's a first icon, there is no need to make it very different. Agree that thus eye is a bit "not human"
  2. Such eye is used in some apps where a user need to hide/show something. Still minimalistic. I would pick that one.
  3. Is pretty recognizable but at this point becomes out of style with other icons. If we optimize for recognition from the first look, that would be a choice
  4. aggressive eye for me

Video call / conf call

image

  1. is original and 2. Is direct feedback from Tim. For me it's a video recording or attach a video. I don't like that I have to re learn that icon.
  2. Since its' a call and it's in a different tab/app. It is logical, but who use this phone these days? (Icon is broadly used across the world)
  3. A monitor with a video call on it... a bit hard to catch what is going on
  4. Just like Zoom icon, I guess these days it is the icon of the video call.
  5. Inside zoom/video call app view. I would pick that one.

Video call / conf call

image

  1. is just 1 with bolder eyes (Tim's feedback).
  2. is more emotional
    I don't have preference here. Do we want more emotional since it's emoji, or calmer classical smile?

image

  1. In style with everything, harder to recognize. Would anybody use that icon at all? I know that some people don't know about Crtrl+V and just prefer to pick a file instead of dragging it to the field.
  2. Easier to recognize, grabs attention. Looks nice :smile: If we pick emotional smile (big mouth) this image icon would balance it out.

Link icon

image.png

  1. Looks nice and big and modern. Yes its not easy to recognize. I pick this one.
  2. Closer to classic link
  3. Bootstrap's icon for a link

Lists icons

image.png

Sorry for not giving option where there are 3 lines with dots for each. It's redundant and boring.

  1. Minimalistic. I don't think it's super confusing or looks like a menu icon
  2. More understandable. I saw some big app is using such approach.

Poll icon

image.png

  1. For me poll is about voting, while voting is about people. usually when we we use such icon in organization we want to get people's opinions and in Zulip all people are listed, so its not about cold stats but who choose what. I pick this one.
  2. is the same tuned 5. Poll is about picking something right?
  3. It's not align left because.... I made a border around it?
  4. another attempt on "some selection out of options".
  5. It's exact twitter icon. I'm not sure we can used (I don't think anybody care).
I strongly agree with you on the poll icon for the reasons you cite. We should avoid options 2 and 5 in particular.

I disagree about showing a user icon for the poll — I don't think I'd know what that meant if I saw it, I'd probably guess it was a way to add @ mentions or something?

I agree that 2 and 5 should be avoided.

I think 2, 4, and 6 are the clearest. I don't have a strong preference between them.

Here's what I see as the Twitter icon — I think it's clear and reasonable. (oh, I see Vlad Korobov got bitten by markdown lists not letting you skip numbers: 6 is the twitter icon, not 5).

I went through and annotated my preferences prior to reading Vlad Korobov 's:

icons-preferred.png

I didn't pick a poll icon, because I wasn't thrilled with any of the options. I wouldn't go with the thumbs up/down, because to me that hints that it's a binary yes/no vote, rather than the open-ended type of poll we support.
I find Vlad Korobov 's reasoning on the video call icon compelling, and am inclined to switch my vote. :)

I got side-railed by compose box experience design. So here is the update on this.

  • Video reasoning and explanations.
  • Interactive prototype to try (don't forget to switch to 100% scale)
  • Static images of the design:

compose to stream

compose to PM
7 messages were moved from this topic to #feedback > saving drafts by Alya Abbott.
One relevant bit of compose box context is the "send later" feature, which we expect to add this spring: #11227.
Super cool, thanks for sharing! I think it's really great to play with ideas that are a little more different from what we have now, so that we can explore the solution space.

A few thoughts and questions:

  1. The left-side buttons column is interesting! It definitely feels like a natural place for a PM/stream message switcher to me. I'm less sure about the three buttons below, but we've been struggling with where to place them, so it could be a way out of that dilemma.

  2. I think I like the design direction of moving the formatting/insertion buttons inside the compose box visually. The part that's not really working for me, is all the blank space above the "send" button. Would it be reasonable to make the compose box go all the way across, and put the "send" button alongside the compose buttons (outside of the scrollable area)?

  3. I guess the "To:" is aligned with the compose placeholder text, but to me it feels too far to the right, especially if I'm not looking too closely.

  4. Can you talk about the decision to make the compose box a bit wider? It's been growing on me, but I'm curious about the motivation.

  5. What are your thoughts on showing stream privacy icons in the compose box (which we currently do for non-public streams, and have thought about doing for public streams as well). It might seem funny/inconsistent to have a hash in the stream/PM switcher followed by a lock in the stream name area. But maybe it's OK? Switching the hash selector to a lock, etc., could also be an option.

  6. Where would you place the #design > narrow to topic/pms when composing button we plan to add?

  7. I'm liking the grey background for the compose area, and the scrollable formatting buttons concept seems promising to me!

As Evy Kassirer 's question reminded me, #18555 is another compose feature to keep in mind. The proposed design for it has:

There is a new "Save and clear" button (tooltip: "Save as draft and clear compose box"). Perhaps bottom right (near the "Send") button is a good placement.
Good questions. Lets talk about that on the meeting
